questions.text: Wax bath therapy is used in the management of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Wax bath therapy is used in Hansen's disease.

Indication:

In all patients of Hansen, without any active blister or wounds over the hands

It increases the blood flow to skin, makes the skin soft and increases activity of sweat glands.

Reference: IAL textbook of Leprosy, 2nd edition, chapter 17

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the reactional states of leprosy?
questions.solution:
• In acute reactional state of leprosy, blood picture can appear that of leukemoid reaction. i.e. the total leucocyte count may increase 20k to 50kcells/ microliter.
  • There can be anemia due to rapid hemolysis, which causes increase in bilirubin and presence of urobilinogen in urine.

Reference: IAL textbook of Leprosy, 2nd edition, chapter 20

choices.text: 3 skin lesion, single nerve involvement, SSS negative

questions.text: Which of the following is a type of multibacillary leprosy?
questions.solution:
Paucibacillary leprosy:

  • 5 or less than 5 lesion
  • Sss negative
  • No or single nerve involvement

Multibacillary leprosy:

  • 6 or more skin lesion
  • SSS positive
  • Two or more nerves

Reference: IAL textbook of Leprosy, 2nd edition, chapter 5

choices.text: Rifampicin inhibits DNA dependent RNA polymerases

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the MDT for Leprosy except:
questions.solution:
• Dapsone (DDS)
    • Folate antagonist
    • Decreases PABA in folic acid synthesis
    • Decreases dihidropteroic acid synthesis
    • Bacteriostatic drug

Reference: IAL textbook of Leprosy, 2nd edition, chapter 10

choices.text: Starting the patient on topical retinoids
IQ assessment to detect mental retardation

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with the following to your OPD. She has developed those since infancy and are now increasing in size and number. Which of the following is not required in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The following image shows adenoma sebaceum/angiofibromas.
  • They begin in infancy and may sometimes become extensive during puberty and then remain unchanged.
  • Firm descrete, red brown, telangiectatic papules present over the cheeks, naso labial furrows and ears rarely,
  • They may be numerous and may rarely form large cauliflower like masses

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 80.10

questions.text: Which of the following organism does not produce any florescence under woods lamp?
questions.solution:
• Pseudomonas produce green florescence due to pyoverdine
  • Corynebacterium minumittisum produce coral red florescence due to production of coproporphyrin 3
  • Only microsporum species of dermatophyte show florescence due to production of pteridine
  • Propiobacterium acne produce florescence due to coproporphyrin production

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 80.10

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reticulate hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
• Dowling Degos disease:
    • This is a progressive, disorder of pigmentation, charac-terized by flexural, pigmented reticulate macules and comedone-like papules on the back and neck.
    • It is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and the gene defect is believed to be localized to keratin
  • Dyskeratosis Congenita:
    • There is a lacy reticulate telangiectatic hyper-pigmentation interspersed with areas of hypopigmentation a seen on the face, neck, trunk and upper thighs.
    • Atrophy and cyanosis of the dorsal aspects of the hands and feet with hyperkeratosis and hyperhidrosis of palms and soles may also be present.
    • The mucosa shows leukokeratosis which may involve the pharynx, anorectal and urogenital mucosae.
    • The nails are dystrophic with pterygium formation and the hair is thin, lustreless and sparse
  • Acropigmentation of Kitamura:
    • This gradually progressive disorder has a onset in the first to second decade of life.
    • The lesions are slightly depressed, sharply demarcated black/brown macules localized to the dorsum of the hands and feet.
    • These increase in number and spread centripetally with age.
    • The presence of small pits that cause a break in the epidermal ridge patterns on the palms and rarely on the dorsum of fingers, is a diagnostic feature.

Reference: Rooks Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 70.3

questions.text: A case of 12-years-old boy presents to you with boggy swelling and easily pluckable hair. What would be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tinea capitis is most commonly caused by Microsporum Canis.

  • Second MCC of tenia capitis is trichophyton tonsurans.
  • It is never caused by Epidermophyton as it does not involve hair.
  • It presents with localized non-cicatricial alopecia, itching, scaling with or without boggy swelling of scalp & easily pluckable hair.
  • Tenia capitis is diagnosed by potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mounts of hair & scale.
  • Treatment: Griseofulvin is DOC

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 32

questions.text: Bandlike infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermo-epidermal junction, and 'saw-tooth' rete ridges are diagnostic histological features of:
questions.solution:
• Scanning power view of lichen planus shows a lichenoid reaction pattern characterized by the combination of degeneration of the basal layer of the epidermis and a band like lymphocytic infiltrate obscuring the dermo epidermal junction.
  • There is irregular epidermal hyperplasia forming a characteristic saw-tooth appearance with wedge-shaped hyper granulosis.
  • The basal layer of the epidermis exhibits vacuolar degeneration with typically prominent necrosis of individual keratinocytes.
  • The inflammatory infiltrate is chiefly lymphocytic and forms a dense band in the superficial dermis.

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 42

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient, presented to you with the following (image). On elaborating the history, the patient was tested HIV + few months back, but he didn't take ART. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Kaposi's sarcoma is a type of cancer that forms in the lining of blood and lymph vessels.
  • The tumors (lesions) of Kaposi's sarcoma typically appear as painless violaceous spots on the legs, feet or face.
  • Lesions can also appear in the genital area, mouth or lymph nodes.

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 30

choices.text: Squamous cell skin cancer develops in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis and occurs due to mutated keratinocytes.
Squamous cell skin cancer develops in the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and occurs due to mutated basal cells.
Squamous cell skin cancer develops in the stratum basale layer of the epidermis and occurs due to mutated melanocytes.
Squamous cell skin cancer develops in the stratum granulosum layer of the epidermis and occurs due to mutated squamous cells.

questions.text: You're providing teaching to a patient diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma on the face. In your teaching, you are providing education on how this type of skin cancer develops. What information will you include in your patient education?
questions.solution:
Squamous cell skin cancer develops in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis and occurs due to mutated keratinocytes.

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 3

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not associated with lower segment hemangioma?
questions.solution:
• Facial segmental haemangioma
  • Posterior fossa malformations, haemangiomas, arterial anomalies, cardiac anomalies, eye abnormalities, sternal pit/supraumbilical raphe (PHACES association)
  • Lower body segmental haemangioma
  • Lower body IH, uro-genital anomalies, ulceration, myelopathy, bony deformities, ano-rectal malformations, arterial anomalies and renal anomalies (LUMBAR association)
  • Spinal dysraphism, ano-genital anomalies, cutaneous anomalies, renal and urological anomalies, lumbosacral IH (SACRAL association)
  • Perineal IH, external genitalia, malformations, lipo-myelomeningocele, vesico-renal abnormalities, imperforate anus (PELVIS association)

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology chapter 117

choices.text: Refer to the neurosurgeon for surgical sympathectomy
Council him that no cure exists for the condition
Advise iontophoresis and topical application of aluminium chloral hydrate solution
Post him for botulinum toxin injection

questions.text: An 18-year-old male, preparing to get recruited in the army comes to you with complaints of hyperhidrosis over the palms and soles. He has been investigated for the secondary causes of hyperhidrosis however none has been reported. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• There are many topical and systemic agents available to treat hyperhidrosis.
  • First-line therapy for hyperhidrosis includes over-the-counter aluminum chloride hexahydrate 20% for 3 to 4 nights, then nightly as needed.
  • Iontophoresis two to three times weekly and botulinum toxin A injections every 3 to 4 weeks are effective if patients fail topical and oral drug therapy. Iontophoresis is a long-term treatment, and at best, its effects are mild. Many agents can be added to the water, but compliance with this treatment is low
  • More invasive therapeutic measures are available, including sympathectomy or local excision as a last resort. Many surgical procedures have been developed to manage hyperhidrosis, including sympathectomy, radiofrequency ablation, subcutaneous liposuction, and surgical excision of affected areas when first line treatment fails.

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 85

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with thick skin on his face, forearms, and on the dorsum of his hands. He reports blisters that rupture, leaving open sores that heal slowly and that they occur most often after he visits the beach with his family. Family history is insignificant. Vitals are currently within normal limits. Physical examination is significant for skin lesions that are erosions, bulla, milia, hyperpigmented patches, and hypopigmented atrophic scars. Which of the following is the best treatment for the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with a history of photosensitivity and Hep C infection. Phlebotomy is the appropriate treatment for this condition.
  • Any condition leading to iron overload in the patient is a clear indication for phlebotomy and, in such cases, is preferred over hydroxychloroquine. Different protocols have been tried; one unit or 450 ml of blood removed every two weeks. Strict serial monitoring of ferritin levels is done, and a downward trend in serum ferritin level is the goal of phlebotomy (till a ferritin level of less than 20 ng/ml is seen)

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 51

choices.text: Defined as migration of cells from stratum basale to stratum to spinosum
Epidermal turn over time is 8 weeks
There is persistence of nucleus in the keratinocyte through out the process

questions.text: True about the keratinization :
questions.solution:
• Defined as migration and maturation of cells from stratum basale to stratum corneum
  • nucleus in the keratinocyte dies, stratum corneum are anucleated
  • metabolism and size of keratinocyte decreases from basale to corneum.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 31

choices.text: Lamina lucida, lamina densa and sub lamina densa forms basement membrane
Keratin intermediate filaments join basement membrane to dermis
Anchoring fibrils joins statum basale to basement membrane
Bullous pemphigoid is occurs due to damage to anchoring fibrils

questions.text: True about basement membrane zone:
questions.solution:
• Anchoring fibrils join basement membrane to dermis
  • Keratin intermediate filaments joins statum basale to basement membrane
  • Epidermolysis bullosa occurs due to damage to anchoring fibrils

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 3

choices.text: Cofactor for the enzyme that hydroxylates proline and lysine
Forms a complex which cleaves pre-procollagen
Mediates the formation of the triple helix of procollagen

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the healthcare provider with malaise and easy bruising. Also, there is evidence of gum disease and several loose teeth. she has a deficiency of a water-soluble vitamin. What is the role of this vitamin in collagen synthesis?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin C is an essential cofactor for the enzyme lysyl hydroxylase that hydroxylates proline and lysine.
  • Without hydroxyproline, collagen is less stable because of the lack of cross-linking between the collagen strands.
  • Vitamin C, ascorbic acid, or L-ascorbic acid, is a vitamin found in food and used as a dietary supplement. Vitamin C is used to prevent and treat scurvy.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 31

questions.text: A toddler is brought to the clinic for evaluation of newly developed skin lesions. On examination, multiple vesicles have coalesced and ruptured, forming purulent honey-colored exudates. What is next best step?
questions.solution:
• Impetigo is a common infection of the superficial layers of the epidermis that is highly contagious and most commonly caused by gram-positive bacteria. It most commonly presents as erythematous plaques with a yellow crust and may be itchy or painful. The lesions are highly contagious and spread easily.
  • Impetigo is a disease of children who reside in hot humid climates. The infection may be bullous or non-bullous. The infection typically affects the face but can also occur in any other part of the body that has an abrasion, laceration, insect bite or other trauma.
  • Diagnosis is typically based on the symptoms and clinical manifestations alone.
  • Treatment involves topical and oral antibiotics and symptomatic care

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 31

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with papules and vesicles on right side of her forehead. She had burning pain and hypersensitivity. Her pain is localised to right supraorbital area and right aspect of dorsum of her nose. What is clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Aetiology: Varicella-zoster virus. After an attack of chicken pox, virus lies dormant in sensory root ganglia. Zoster is a manifestation of its reactivation.
  • Morphology: Very painful, segmental eruption of grouped papules and vesicles on an erythematous, slightly oedematous base. Self-limiting. Crust in a week.
  • Sites: Thoracic intercostal nerves, ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve.

Reference: Illustrated Synopsis of Dermatology and Sexually Transmitted Disease, Neena Khanna 4th edition page277

choices.text: They are present over the glans penis
They are present on the lips
They are not present on foreskin
They are present on labia minora

questions.text: True about the distribution of eccrine sweat glands:
questions.solution:
Distribution of eccrine gland:

They are present over the whole skin surface, Including glans penis and foreskin

They are absent on lips, labia minora and external ear canal

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 31

choices.text: Inflammation around the nail involving the nail folds
White creamy patch over the tongue
Soreness and cracking at the angles of mouth

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true with respect to perleche?
questions.solution:
Soreness and cracking at the angles of mouth are seen in perleche. Also, called as angular stomatitis. Type of oral mucosal candidiasis

Reference: Rooks' textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 31

questions.text: In which of the following disorders is the following finding seen:
The structure of nail plate is derived from:
questions.solution:
The structure of nail plate is derived from nail matrix

Nail matrix is of 3 types:

  1. Ventral nail matrix
  2. Intermediate nail matrix
  3. Dorsal nail matrix

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 95

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of total nail avulsion:
questions.solution:
Total nail avulsion:

  • Subungual hematoma
  • Chronic paronychia unresponsive to treatment
  • Ingrown toe nail

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 95

questions.text: The circumscribed alteration in the colour of skin is known as:
questions.solution: Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 3

questions.text: A 55-year-old farmer from India presents with lesions on his feet (shown below). Punch biopsy of the area reveals sinus tracts filled with neutrophils and dark black grains with fungal hyphae. What is the most common causative agent associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
• This clinical vignette is an example of Eumycetoma which is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Nocardia brasiliensis is one of the causes of eumycetoma, however, it is not the most common cause.
  • Nocardia brasiliensis also leads to the production of yellow-brown grain and not dark and black grain.
  • Madurella mycetomatis is the most common causative agent of eumycetoma worldwide. Etiologic agents of eumycetoma are classified by the type of grain produced.
  • Dark and black grains are produced by many fungal organisms including Madurella mycetomatis.

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 55

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother for the evaluation of a rash around the eyes and mouth. His mother states that the rash appeared two weeks ago and seems very itchy because the boy often scratches his eyes.. On examination, the patient is playful and alert. He has scaly, erythematous skin surrounding both eyes and his mouth. Expiratory wheezes can be heard in the lower lung fields bilaterally. What is this most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Atopic dermatitis, also known as eczema, is a skin condition characterized by itchy, erythematous plaques on the skin.
  • It is highly associated with other atopic conditions such as asthma, allergic rhinitis, and food allergies.
  • Patients with eczema will have increased serum IgE, suggesting an autoimmune allergic response.
  • Eczema is common in infants and children and often occurs on the face, especially in the folds around the eyes and mouth. It will start by affecting the extensor surfaces in infants.
  • However, it is more commonly found on flexor surfaces later in life

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 45

questions.text: A 55 year old female presents with the tinea infection as shown in the figure. Which nail lacquer will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Nail lacquers used in onychomycosis are:

  • Ciclopirox olamine 8%
  • Amrolfine 5 %
  • Terbinafine 10%

Newer agents like:

  • Tavaborole 5%
  • Efinaconazole 10%

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 32

choices.text: There is triangular lunula on nail plate
Patella is large and always present

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about the nail patella syndrome?
questions.solution:
Nail patella syndrome:

  • It is an autosomal dominant condition
  • Lunula on nails is triangular instead of lunular
  • Patella is small, irregular or absent
  • Iliac horns are present

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 69

questions.text: A female presents to the clinic with non-itchy gritty black nodules on her scalp hair. She denies any hair loss and pain in the scalp. Microscopic examination with 10% KOH revealed nodules on the hair shaft which were made up of closely packed brown hyphae held in a mass by a cement-like substance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Black piedra predominantly affects scalp hairs, characterized by firmly adherent black hard nodules that are gritty on palpation. Although asymptomatic, the fungus grows into the hair shaft causing hair to fracture easily.
  • In a case of black piedra, microscopic examination of nodules with 10% to 20% KOH show the presence of closely packed brown hyphae held in a mass by a cement-like substance. The center of the nodules reveals many asci containing ascospores with thick hyphal strands at the periphery.
  • Black piedra is a fungal infection of the hair shafts. The appropriate treatment of this condition would involve the application of antifungal agents like 2% ketoconazole.

Reference: Rooks' textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 32

choices.text: Rapid infiltration into the underlying tissues

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department for the evaluation of a nodular lesion on her leg for the past 6 months that has gradually grown in size.It is non-tender on palpation and central dimpling is observed when the lesion is pinched at the edges. Which of the following best describes the course of the patient's skin condition if no medical or surgical treatment is provided?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is a dermatofibroma, a superficial benign fibrous histiocytoma.
  • Dermatofibromas are slow-growing lesions that can affect any part of the body but have a predilection for the extremities. Clinically these lesions are firm, non-tender, nodular with or without overlying skin changes, and a smooth surface.
  • Dermatofibromas are benign lesions with excellent prognosis. Spontaneous resolution or no change in the lesions will likely be observed even if no medical or surgical treatment is provided.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 137

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to you complaining of a sandpaper-like pink area on his forehead. Physical examination of his forehead reveals male-pattern baldness and thin, adherent, yellow-colored skin lesions that feel rough to the touch (see image). Which of the following conditions would the patient most likely develop if this skin condition is left untreated?
questions.solution:
• Actinic keratosis is a premalignant condition for squamous cell carcinoma that results from significant lifetime exposure to sunlight.
  • Actinic keratoses are characteristically thin, adherent, and rough to palpation; these lesions can progress to cutaneous horns that can be detected by their sandpaper-like texture and are clinically indistinguishable from squamous cell carcinoma.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 142

questions.text: Which of the following dermatologic conditions may be associated with reactive arthritis?
questions.solution:
Reactive Arthritis and Spondyloarthropathy

  • Keratodermia blennorrhagicum, also referred to as pustulosis palmoplantaris, is clinically and histologically indistinguishable from pustular psoriasis but is typically confined to the palms and soles and is usually associated with other characteristic features of reactive arthritis such as urethritis and conjunctivitis.
  • Circinate balanitis produces a serpiginous inflammatory lesion of the glans penis and is another feature classically associated with reactive arthritis.
  • A variety of oral lesions have also been described, ranging from painless shiny patches on the tongue, palate, and mucosa to oral ulcerations.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 142

choices.text: A predilection for the upper limbs

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with Kaposi sarcoma?
questions.solution:
• Kaposi sarcoma is associated with HIV and HHV-8 infection.
  • Not associated with herpes simplex virus
  • It presents with violaceous plaques and papules
  • Also has visceral involvement
  • 4 types:
    • Epidemic: (HIV associated)
    • Endemic : seen in Africans, involves Lymph nodes
    • Transplant associated: involves viscera and lymph nodes
    • Sporadic form

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 31

questions.text: A 2-year-old patient presents with polyuria and polydipsia. On elaborating history patient has recurrent otitis media. On examination, patient has exophthalmos. Which of the following marker will be seen on IHC?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario presents: Langerhans cell histiocytosis, multifocal form called as Hans Schuller Christian disease.
  • IHC marker:
  • CD1a
  • S100
  • CD 207

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatolog, 9th edition, Chapter 142

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented to the skin OPD with the following. Identify the image?
questions.solution:
• Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory dermatoses, presents in anogenital area in figure of eight pattern. d
  • It is extremely itchy, often distressing
  • It may be accompanied by disparanuia and constipation
  • Treatment of choice is application of high potency topical steroids.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 142

questions.text: A 27 year old male presents to STI clinic with the following. He has history of unprotected homosexual intercourse with complaints of burning micturition and pus discharge from the urethra which of the following investigation should be sent at first?
questions.solution:
Microscopy :

  • Specimen is collected by cotton tipped swab
  • If frank discharge is not present, urethral or prostatic massage is given
  • In females, the specimen is collected from the cervix /urethra/ rectum
  • Gram stain : gram negative intracellular diplococcic with multiple PMNs

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 30, 9th edition

questions.text: Which is the device suitable for laser hair reduction for Indian skin type?
questions.solution:
Long pulse Nd YAG laser is best suited for Indian type

Wavelength : 1064nm

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 160, 9th edition

questions.text: Where is the abnormal protein located in Darier disease?
questions.solution:
An abnormal SERCA2 protein is located in the endoplasmic reticulum and plays a role in the Ca2+ signalling pathway regulating cell to cell adhesion and differentiation of the epidermis

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 160, 9th edition

questions.text: The modified Rodnan score is used in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
The modified Rodnan score is used to assess the degree of skin sclerosis in standardised and reproducible manner.

Maximum score is 51.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 56, 9th edition

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic, by his mother, with complaints of excessive hair fall. The mother also says that the child often scratches his head. Examination of the scalp reveals diffuse scaling with generalized subtle hair loss. Woods light examination of the scalp reveals bright green fluorescence. Which of the following is an appropriate treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The child has got tinea capitis ss. Woods lamp examination reveals bright green fluorescence making the diagnosis of tinea capitis due to Microsporum infection. Treatment is with systemic antifungals.
  • Topical therapy has a role only as an adjunct to the systemic treatment as the penetration inside the hair shaft of topical treatment is poor
  • Hence the drug of choice is oral Griseofulvin.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 32, 9th edition

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the hospital for the evaluation of a painful lesion on her right foot. Three weeks ago, she noticed a localized hardening of her skin on the sole of her foot. The skin examination shows a dry plaque-like lesion under the ball of her foot. Upon examination under a magnifying glass, multiple tiny punctate haemorrhages are seen embedded in the lesions. The palpation of the lesion elicits excessive pain. What is the etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient most likely has a plantar wart.
  • Warts, in general, are a viral infection, benign, but there are reports that sometimes they may become malignant and develop into what is known as verrucous carcinoma.
  • The verrucous carcinoma is a slow-growing tumour and is classified as a well-differentiated squamous cell malignancy that is often mistaken for a common wart.
  • Even though it can occur on any part of the body, it is most common on the plantar surface.
  • Verrucous cancer rarely spreads, but it is locally destructive.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 25, 9th edition

questions.text: A 60 year old male visits your OPD, with complaints of pain and multiple grouped vesicles over the t4 dermatome since 2 days. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for next 5 days?
questions.solution:
The above patient probably has got herpes zoster infection.

FDA approved doses:

  • Acyclovir: 800mg 5 times a day for 5 to 7 days
  • Valacyclovir: 1gm three times a day for 5 days, in severe cases upto 10 days

Reference: Comprehensive Dermatologic Drug therapy, 4th edition, chapter 11.

choices.text: Check if his ART contains Zidovudine
Explain that it is unrelated to HIV

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient, HIV positive on ART since 10 years comes to your clinic with the complaint of darkening of nails since 3 months. What will be your next step?
questions.solution:
• Hyperpigmentation of nails are caused by the disease - HIV itself .
  • Hyperpigmentation of nails is one of the adverse effects of Zidovudine.
  • CD4 counts have no relation to the darkening,

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, Chapter 30, 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a precedent event of sweet's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Triggers of sweet's syndrome:
  • Drugs:
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • G CSF
    • NSAIDS
    • Oral contraceptive
    • Imatinib
    • Some anti hypertensives
    • HAART
  • Autoimmune disorder:
    • Rheumatoid arthritis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Malignancy :
    • Haematological malignancy
    • Lymphomas

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, Chapter 49, 9th edition

choices.text: Most common finding is racoon eyes
Mother is always a known case of lupus erythematosus/ sjogren syndrome
Skin finding resolves within 12 months without scarring
Skin findings are present in about half patients

questions.text: True about neonatal lupus erythematosus is all except :
questions.solution:
• Seen in mothers with positive anti Ro or anti La antibodies.
  • Occurs due to the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to fetus
  • Many times mother is asymptomatic
  • Cutaneous findings: erythematous scaly patches present around the eyes, scalp, trunk and extremities
  • Seen in 50% patients
  • Rash may exacerbate by UV / phototherapy
  • Resolves on its own by 12 months without any evidence of scarring

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, Chapter 52, 9th edition

choices.text: As soon as he feel itching

questions.text: A patient with suspected allergic contact dermatitis due to nickel comes to your clinic for patch testing. You apply the test patch on the upper back. When will you call the patient for further reading?
questions.solution:
• Patch testing is the investigation of choice for allergic contact dermatitis.
  • Preferred site is upper back, lateral aspect of arm.
  • First reading is taken at 48 hours and next at 96 hours.
  • If only one reading is possible then it shoud be taken at 96 hours.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, Chapter 102, 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a type of exogeneous eczema?
questions.solution:
Eczema is divided into two causes:

  • Exogeneous eczema:
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Phyto-photodermatitis
  • Photodermatitis
  • Endogenous eczema:
  • Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Pityriasis alba
  • Asteatotic eczema

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, Chapter 41, 9th edition

questions.text: A 35 year old cement worker comes with the following complaints. Which component of cement is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
• The patient has developed allergic contact dermatitis to cement.
  • Occupational exposure to cement is a major risk factor for the development of chromate allergy.
  • Hexavalent chromium (chromium VI) in cement is a common cause of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD).
  • The prevalence of ACD due to chromate among construction workers has been reported as 10%.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, Chapter 41, 9th edition

questions.text: Slit skin smear can be used for the diagnosis of all except:
questions.solution:
Cytodiagnostic technique used to diagnose various cutaneous dermatoses:

  • Leprosy
  • Cutaneous mastocytosis: metachromatic granules in cytoplasm
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis : LD bodies.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, Chapter 41, 9th edition
